interlinear-text.item: The king and his two sons.

phrase.item: There was a king who had two sons.
When the king passed away, they made his son the king in his place. The elder son [or cousin] became king, but not the younger one.
Then the younger son said: “Our grandfather was king, and after they made your dad the king, they didn't make me [sic].
They made your dad the king, but not mine [sic] Now your dad has passed away, and again they didn't make me the king, but you.”
“Well, it depends on people,
It’s not on me, I also wish they would have made you [the king].”
He became jealous toward
his cousin
because he wanted to become the king.
He said not to worry, then they made food, and that night they had an argument. Briefly, they argued—
in Wakhi we say 'ʃrjat”.

Then, he argued and said, This evening let’s take from the food here. And the king turned his face and the cousin took poison from his pocket and put it on [the king’s] food. prɪt. He noticed that and didn't eat from the pot in front of him,
but he ate from the other side.
Then, when the sun was about to rise, the king, turned the poisoned part of the food on its side.
the poison [the cousin] had put in front of [the king] before.
He ate the poisoned food and died.
He died and he took him to the secret room, and because
‎‎the servants will come and think that he killed his cousin,
the king felt ashamed.
He lay him down straight as any other dead person.
He ordered that he should be buried in the evening.
When they went there in the evening, they saw that he had turned to gold.
The dead body had turned to gold.
From that gold [body] when he took a hand or leg, no matter how much was given, it was fully replenished.
It is never used up.
The city became full of gold.
never-ending.
The one who ate ‘zar’ (poison) turned to 'zar' (gold). He was a ’zar' (jealous) person.
The 'zar' (gold) cames from the person him- or herself.
Whoever is lucky will find it.
